segment.source: Multisampling in Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps
segment.target: Multisampling in Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps

segment.source: Learn how to use multisampling in Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps built with Direct3D.
segment.target: Learn how to use multisampling in Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps built with Direct3D.

segment.source: Multisampling in Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps
segment.target: Multisampling in Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Learn how to use multisampling in Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps built with Direct3D.
segment.target: Learn how to use multisampling in Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps built with Direct3D.

segment.source: Multisampling, also known as multi-sample antialiasing, is a graphics technique used to reduce the appearance of aliased edges.
segment.target: Multisampling, also known as multi-sample antialiasing, is a graphics technique used to reduce the appearance of aliased edges.

segment.source: It works by drawing more pixels than are actually in the final render target, then averaging values to maintain the appearance of a "partial" edge in certain pixels.
segment.target: It works by drawing more pixels than are actually in the final render target, then averaging values to maintain the appearance of a "partial" edge in certain pixels.

segment.source: For a detailed description of how multisampling actually works in Direct3D, see Multisample Anti-Aliasing Rasterization Rules.
segment.target: For a detailed description of how multisampling actually works in Direct3D, see Multisample Anti-Aliasing Rasterization Rules.

segment.source: Multisampling and the flip model swap chain
segment.target: Multisampling and the flip model swap chain

segment.source: UWP apps that use DirectX must use flip model swap chains.
segment.target: UWP apps that use DirectX must use flip model swap chains.

segment.source: Flip model swap chains don't support multisampling directly, but multisampling can still be applied in a different way by rendering the scene to a multisampled render target view, and then resolving the multisampled render target to the back buffer before presenting.
segment.target: Flip model swap chains don't support multisampling directly, but multisampling can still be applied in a different way by rendering the scene to a multisampled render target view, and then resolving the multisampled render target to the back buffer before presenting.

segment.source: This article explains the steps required to add multisampling to your UWP app.
segment.target: This article explains the steps required to add multisampling to your UWP app.

segment.source: How to use multisampling
segment.target: How to use multisampling

segment.source: Direct3D feature levels guarantee support for specific, minimum sample count capabilities, and guarantee certain buffer formats will be available that support multisampling.
segment.target: Direct3D feature levels guarantee support for specific, minimum sample count capabilities, and guarantee certain buffer formats will be available that support multisampling.

segment.source: Graphics devices often support a wider range of formats and sample counts than the minimum required.
segment.target: Graphics devices often support a wider range of formats and sample counts than the minimum required.

segment.source: Multisampling support can be determined at run-time by checking feature support for multisampling with specific DXGI formats, and then checking the sample counts you can use with each supported format.
segment.target: Multisampling support can be determined at run-time by checking feature support for multisampling with specific DXGI formats, and then checking the sample counts you can use with each supported format.

segment.source: Call ID3D11Device::CheckFeatureSupport to find out which DXGI formats can be used with multisampling.
segment.target: Call ID3D11Device::CheckFeatureSupport to find out which DXGI formats can be used with multisampling.

segment.source: Supply the render target formats your game can use.
segment.target: Supply the render target formats your game can use.

segment.source: Both the render target and resolve target must use the same format, so check for both D3D11\_FORMAT\_SUPPORT\_MULTISAMPLE\_RENDERTARGET and D3D11\_FORMAT\_SUPPORT\_MULTISAMPLE\_RESOLVE.
segment.target: Both the render target and resolve target must use the same format, so check for both D3D11\_FORMAT\_SUPPORT\_MULTISAMPLE\_RENDERTARGET and D3D11\_FORMAT\_SUPPORT\_MULTISAMPLE\_RESOLVE.

segment.source: Feature level 9: Although feature level 9 devices guarantee support for multisampled render target formats, support is not guaranteed for multisample resolve targets.
segment.target: Feature level 9: Although feature level 9 devices guarantee support for multisampled render target formats, support is not guaranteed for multisample resolve targets.

segment.source: So this check is necessary before trying to use the multisampling technique described in this topic.
segment.target: So this check is necessary before trying to use the multisampling technique described in this topic.

segment.source: The following code checks multisampling support for all the DXGI\_FORMAT values:
segment.target: The following code checks multisampling support for all the DXGI\_FORMAT values:

segment.source: For each supported format, query for sample count support by calling ID3D11Device::CheckMultisampleQualityLevels.
segment.target: For each supported format, query for sample count support by calling ID3D11Device::CheckMultisampleQualityLevels.

segment.source: The following code checks sample size support for supported DXGI formats:
segment.target: The following code checks sample size support for supported DXGI formats:

segment.source: Note Use ID3D11Device2::CheckMultisampleQualityLevels1 instead if you need to check multisample support for tiled resource buffers.
segment.target: Note Use ID3D11Device2::CheckMultisampleQualityLevels1 instead if you need to check multisample support for tiled resource buffers.

segment.source: Create a buffer and render target view with the desired sample count.
segment.target: Create a buffer and render target view with the desired sample count.

segment.source: Use the same DXGI\_FORMAT, width, and height as the swap chain, but specify a sample count greater than 1 and use a multisampled texture dimension (D3D11\_RTV\_DIMENSION\_TEXTURE2DMS for example).
segment.target: Use the same DXGI\_FORMAT, width, and height as the swap chain, but specify a sample count greater than 1 and use a multisampled texture dimension (D3D11\_RTV\_DIMENSION\_TEXTURE2DMS for example).

segment.source: If necessary, you can re-create the swap chain with new settings that are optimal for multisampling.
segment.target: If necessary, you can re-create the swap chain with new settings that are optimal for multisampling.

segment.target: The following code creates a multisampled render target:

segment.source: The depth buffer must have the same width, height, sample count, and texture dimension to match the multisampled render target.
segment.target: The depth buffer must have the same width, height, sample count, and texture dimension to match the multisampled render target.

segment.source: The following code creates a multisampled depth buffer:
segment.target: The following code creates a multisampled depth buffer:

segment.source: Now is a good time to create the viewport, because the viewport width and height must also match the render target.
segment.target: Now is a good time to create the viewport, because the viewport width and height must also match the render target.

segment.source: The following code creates a viewport:
segment.target: The following code creates a viewport:

segment.source: Render each frame to the multisampled render target.
segment.target: Render each frame to the multisampled render target.

segment.source: When rendering is complete, call ID3D11DeviceContext::ResolveSubresource before presenting the frame.
segment.target: When rendering is complete, call ID3D11DeviceContext::ResolveSubresource before presenting the frame.

segment.source: This instructs Direct3D to peform the multisampling operation, computing the value of each pixel for display and placing the result in the back buffer.
segment.target: This instructs Direct3D to peform the multisampling operation, computing the value of each pixel for display and placing the result in the back buffer.

segment.source: The back buffer then contains the final anti-aliased image and can be presented.
segment.target: The back buffer then contains the final anti-aliased image and can be presented.
